intro: Mentha dubia, commonly known as false mint, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves with a slightly hairy surface. Its small, tubular flowers are usually pale blue to purple, arranged in whorled clusters at the ends of the stems. Mentha dubia is often found in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream sides.
